content.body: Hixie: You have a bogus </colgroup> that is breaking my attempt to run the spec-splitter :-(
oops
um
why is it broken
source seems ok
and the spec-splitter happily dies and then uploads it non-existent output and thus deletes the multipage spec
what's broken about it?
<table class=apple-table-examples><col></colgroup><col><col><col><thead><tr><th> <th>2008 <th>2007 <th>2006
wtf
that must be a libhtml bug
or libxml
or whatever we're using
That's quite possible
I've written a blog post about how to use HTML5's new sectioning elements.
Would anyone like to review it before I publish? I want to be sure I'm making good recommendations. I'd rather the article reduce, not add, to the confusion around these elements.
(I'm using libxml for parsing, because html5lib is unbearably slow)
hober: can't review right now, but i'd be happy to do so after my meeting which starts in 10 minutes
(Also, this is the index document, not the source document)
lxml.etree.XMLSyntaxError: Unexpected end tag : colgroup, line 29957, column 53
Hixie: ok, I'll /msg you the link; please review at your leisure
(using etree.HTMLParser)
Is this something that is easily fixable without me doing anything?
hober, I'll take a look.
annevk2: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/introduction.html - now with added TOC
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/commands.html - it's a little peculiar on certain pages, but I think it's probably about correct
Philip`, I love the new TOCs.
Hmm, the toc.js script messes things up a bit :-(
Hixie: Is there some way toc.js could be disabled on the mini-TOCs in the multipage view?
temporarily switched to the html5lib parser, but it's too resource-intensive for him to be particularly happy running it
is proud of his table examples
hi all
Philip`, sweet
Philip`, for the introduction page the "full table of contents" should probably not be there
Philip`, and the link above it, it's not present on other pages either
annevk3: I blame Hixie for that
since toc.js adds the full table of contents automatically
ah
i see, it's also present on full table of contents
maybe toc.js should recognize a class name or something
Hixie: It's all your fault :-(
annevk3: I think I have to use class="toc" to get the right styling, but could add an extra class to make toc.js ignore it
that could work, or hixie adds a class to the main toc; either way
Hixie, pretty sure that if the fieldset is disabled the contents of the legend element are too
in Opera they are
which is per spec
Hixie, so the fieldset example will never work

Hixie, I'd move the checkbox into a

or so before the fieldset
annevk3: should we fix that?
the spec i mean?
seems like a reasonable use case
anyway i gotta sleep now
I guess we could
would it work to just say that controls within the <legend> don't get disabled along with the fieldset?
spec-wise it's no problem
just wondering about implementation complexity with dynamic updates and all
not more crazy I guess than other stuff, but the question is whether it's worth it
I'd be more convinced if there were real sites built with equivalent functionality
sites prolly will if the styling issue gets solved
tries to work out whether he should be using zh or zh-CN or zh-Hans
Languages are too confusing :-(
don't bother tagging it?
tries to work out which alias table Safari is using for ICU
zh-x-Philip`
annevk2: I need to at least have some language code for the filename
so I might as well use the correct one
why is that?
Because of a pointless desire for correctness
carry on then :)
So which one is correcter? :-)
Philip`: zh-CN looks wronger/older; zh-Hans is preciser (so likelier to be incorrect).
(Apart from that, CN would be associated with mainland China, and Hans with simplified ideograms, which originated there.)
was to be expected: http://meiert.com/en/blog/20090911/html-5-or-html5/
Philip`, zh seems safest if you're unsure
http://blog.whatwg.org/spelling-html5 - "Isn’t 5 a *version number*? As in HTML 4.01. Shouldn’t it actually be HTML 5?"
That seems a good argument to call it "HTML5", so people don't think it's a version number
and, new grouping is nice btw
annevk2: I'm sure it's simplified Chinese, written by someone from mainland China, so the issue is just what code to use (rather than what language it is)
The person who wrote it called it zh_cn, but e.g. http://www.w3.org/International/articles/language-tags/ seems to indicate zh-Hans is newer and more consistent and accurate
are you sure it's not zh-Hant?
anyway, http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5646 seems to suggest a couple of those are at least out of date (though still valid for backcompat reasons)
Hant/Hans means traditional/simplified Han characters (ideograms).
The use of CN to mean Hans is obsolete, but probably still fine to indicate mainland China.
(as I understand it, anyway)
language tags certainly became a whole lot more complicated since I last looked at it
Hierarchically constructed tags like zh-Hans-CN are nice in theory, but I am not sure they are handled reasonably by matching algorithms.

annevk2: Glad you like it. I tried to choose clear and uncontroversial categories, but the labels are not completely self-explanatory (e.g., Mac CJK encodings belong to the CJK group, not to the Mac group). I hope I did not change anything in the process.
oh, I haven't checked that
it makes it a lot easier to compare browsers anyway
once the data is more complete I plan to write a scraper that allows you to run comparisons on it
Well, I tried to be careful.
That is a good idea. We might want to add the IANA registry as a "browser" as well.
yeah
unfortunately it seems i'm booked for most of the weekend at least until sunday evening so it'll have to wait a little
hears loud roar of small jet engines, and looks up at window, and sees some of the red arrows flying fairly low and fast
http://philip.html5.org/demos/rdfa/google-rich-snippets.html - it's a bit pathetic really
wau
Looks like something you'd make with regular expressions :)
sighs at British train prices
So a ticket from Reading to Leuchars is the same price as one from Birmingham New Street to Leuchars. That makes sense.
That's untrue. There is a slight difference.
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-rdf-in-xhtml-tf/2009Sep/0124.html
hopes he didn't make too many stupid mistakes
Philip`: I expect one response will be "But nobody is going to use v:g/#Person so it's just silly to support it"
Then I might respond that some people seriously considered xmlns:http="http:" as a valid trick to transition to non-prefix-based URLs, which would be broken by this kind of thing
They were silly too
Recent experience indicates RDFa people are happy with requiring specific behaviour for invalid input anyway, even when it's weird edge cases
(and any disagreement is just about how explicitly and clearly it needs to be specified, vs being determined by the spec authors' intentions)

"we will [...] deviate from the standard in some cases to be forgiving of webmaster errors.  For example, we expect that some webmasters will forget the xmlns attribute entirely." (says a person from Google)
Hooray for standards and interoperability!
I think the Google parsing behavior sounds reasonable, at least as a forgiving, "real-world" processor of RDFa bits and pieces that survive copy&paste
It seems like the extent to which they're deviating from RDFa-as-specified is the extent to which RDFa-as-specified isn't a web-ready tech...
Should an element with display: none be included in the outline?
If they want something that's forgiving and web-ready and works in the real world, and don't think RDFa is suitable for that, then they shouldn't pretend to support RDFa
Then they could simplify it further (e.g. not use xmlns at all), and would no longer be flagrantly violating standards
It'd be good if they documented whatever they implement, too
indeed
I'm just saying I think the RDFa folks should take a different lesson than the one I think they'll take from this
Steve^: Yes
since CSS is just an optional rendering thing
Maybe <whatever hidden> shouldn't be included, though
("shouldn't" in terms of what's sensible, not necessarily what the spec says)
It is good to avoid the "untitled section" in an outline
(For future reference: That quote is from http://www.w3.org/mid/6934bc6b0909120945l7e721b90pda3ec06ca4d4c917⊙mgc which doesn't exist since it hasn't hit the list yet)
(The Google RDFa quote, that is)
Steve^: Yes. Indeed if you use one of the techniques that shows things to AT but not to ordinary browsers (e.g. the left -10000 thing) it is even better
OK, I've published my blog post about how to use sectioning elements correctly http://edward.oconnor.cx/2009/09/using-the-html5-sectioning-elements
hober, did you make any changes since I reviewed it earlier?
only a handful of litle edits; nothing major
wonders if trying to change at Clapham Junction is a good idea
